Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract for EAGER: Self-Assembly of Complex Systems
Intellectual Merit:
Self-assembly is a model for how individual components arrange themselves through local interactions to form organized structures. It originated as a model for construction of nanotechnology. The theory of complex systems describes many phenomena in nature, from human intelligence and evolving communities of organisms to human social networks, economies, and cultures. In these systems, complexity emerges in ways that is not immediately obvious from an understanding of the component parts and the relationships between them. In this project, self-assembly will be investigated as a mechanism for creation of complex systems. Self-assembly can be shown to be equivalent to other models of complex systems. In addition, it can be programmed like a computer. A goal of this project is to develop efficient ways to program self-assembly to produce interesting complex systems, which have practical applications. As a beginning to this, we have developed a mapping of self-assembly onto graphs that enables us to use an efficient algorithm to determine the system that is constructed. Thus, self-assembly should be able to generate complex systems and to provide efficient and realistic simulation of those types of systems. In the project, the self-assembly algorithms will be applied to automatic content generation for games, in which the self-assembly automatically creates situations and non-player characters with which players of the game interact. The conjecture is that this will provide more dynamic and realistic game environments, and moreover, will be an interesting test-bed for investigation of the relationship between self-assembly and complex systems.
Broader Impacts:
This research integrates ideas from chemistry, physics, biology, and computer science to relate self-assembly to complex systems, and to produce potentially transformative tools that will not only improve understanding of complex systems, but also form the basis for innovative complex systems in a variety of application domains. These include nanotechnology, artificial intelligence, art, literature, and computer games. There are many natural phenomena (i.e. human intelligence, living systems) for which traditional symbolic models of computation are only able to capture a part of their essential capabilities and characteristics. Human language is an example. This research conceivably could result in software that is able to produce target systems that capture some of the capability, adaptability, and complexity that is observed in nature. If successful, the project could result in a new paradigm for realistic and complex behavior through computer programs, and would potentially impact not only nanotechnology, but also applications that require automatic generation of realistic content. Moreover, our models of self-assembly can generate this content in tractable ways. In addition, under the direction of the investigator, graduate and undergraduate students will work together in a team on this project, and will be educated in the unique multidisciplinary approach that has been proposed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Self-assembly is the unsupervised aggregation of simple component parts into organized structures with potentially complex function. It seems to be ubiquitous in nature, from membrane formation and protein folding to assembly of cells into complex organism. Self-assembly of nanostructures has a great deal of promise to construct materials with enhanced or interesting properties. This has the potential for technological advances in a number of areas, as well as enhanced economic opportunities for better or new products. Some of the areas of intersest are biomedical, energy, electronics, and computation. In this project, by analyzing the relationship of self-assembly to other complex systems, we hope to better understand the fundamental difficulties and capabilities of self-assembly, and to develop design tools to accelerate practical applications.

Since self-assembly is a metaphor for organization of comlexity in biological systems, it should be related to other models of complex systems. For instance, Ising spin glasses  are prototypical models for complex systems, such as frustrated magnetic materials, protein folding, neural networks, and human cultural and economic interactions. By studying self-assembly in this context, the goal is to use methods from other fields to better understand and manipulate self-assembly.

There are two main outcomes for the project. In the first, by formalizing the relationship between models of self-assembly and Ising spin models, a dichotomy between easy and hard to quantify instances of self-assembly were found. Basically, in the easy instances the number of configurations of the self-assembly can be counted efficiently. This allows probabilities of certain outcomes to be computed efficiently, which might produce more effective design tools. The dichotomy was found by mapping self-assembly onto graphs that represent the different ways that the component parts can interact with each other. If this graph could be drawn without crossing lines on a sheet of paper, then, the computation of its properties could be done in an efficient way. This is important because it gives a way to quantify the complexity of the self-assembly, and therefore, it feasibility to achieve in the laboratory. Moreover, this model tells us when the thermodynamic properties of the self-assembly system can be effectively computed.

The second main outcome is the concept of probabilistic pattern assembly. Most frequently, self-assembly designs are geared toward exact, deterministic pattern formation. Real assembly in the lab, however, is never so perfect. Thus, in this model, we have relaxed the requirements for perfection in an effort to characterize what is actually achievable in a laboratory. A model that was used for inspiration was percolation, in which conduits for fluid flow either exist or not. At a given set of paramters, there are many patterns that can percolation. Thus, no single pattern is required. So far, we have identified several classes of patterns that can or cannot be probabilistically assembled. This is important not only to bring the theory of self-assembly closer to the exerimentalist, but also because many useful materials, like concrete or light-responsive patterns, do not require exact structure. Along the way, we have designed several designs for self-asembly that achieve probabilistically assembled patterns, and that might have practical use to generate patterns in materials for some of the applications noted above. During this project, we have developed a model for probabilistically assemblable patterns, which with further development might tell us what types of patterns might be efficiently assmbled in a statistical sense. Again, this type of model informs laboratory work and represents progress to design self-assemblies for practical applications.

Two graduate students have recieved their Masters degree...
